title: Functional analysis of the roles of nematode effectors in the susceptible plant-nematode interaction
segmentation: So first of all, thank you very much to the organizers for inviting me to talk about nematode, effective today.
So as they said, I'm I'm John Jones.
But please understand that this is not all my own work.

Work like this is only done in large teams and I've acknowledged everybody at the end and I also have a position at the University of Saint Andrews, so I'm a joint appointment between the Hudson Institute and Saint Andrews.
So I work with plant parasitic nematodes.
You guys will have heard talks and seen posters yesterday about what damaging pathogens they are.
It's it's extremely difficult to work out exactly the costs of the damage caused by nematodes, and they live underground there.
Microscopically small.
It's very difficult to understand exactly the damage they're doing, but.
There are figures that have been calculated that say they eat about 10% of the crops that we try to grow.

The most damaging species by some margin are the root knot nematodes, which you heard about yesterday, and this is what they do to a root system and the system nematodes, and the reason I have a job is because potato cyst nematodes are an extremely damaging pathogen.
In the UK.
There an increasing problem because a lot of the chemicals that farmers used to control plant parasitic nematodes are being withdrawn on environmental grounds.
So as well as being damaging, pathogens are also fascinating from a scientific point of view.
In my opinion, they are by a trophic pathogens.

It's often difficult to imagine a complex multi cellular animal as anything other than a herbivore adventure in mature, but these are by a trophic pathogens, so this is a slide showing the key stages of the potato cyst.
Nematode Liberty repelled a life cycle.
We have a survival stage.
The cysts that exist in the soil when they detect a host crop growing nearby.
In this case, potato.
The second stage juvenile will hatch.
It finds the root.
Here's one.
We've stained red caught in the act of infecting the root of a plant.
They then induced this structure inside the roots of the plant cell as Sin City and it's a large multinucleate feeding site.
They can only do this once.
OK, so the nematode needs to induce the formation of this structure in the plant and then it needs to keep it alive for up to six weeks.

The plant is very good at killing pathogens and will be trying to destroy this feeding site, but the nematode is able to keep it alive while it develops over to the adult female or to the adult male through a series of notes.
So these are by a trophic pathogens.
And they have to keep their host alive for weeks and weeks, otherwise it is fatal for the parasite.

So because this is such a damaging pathogen in the UK, anbi cause it's also an interesting scientific problem ourselves at the Hutton Institute, along with Leeds University, Rothamsted and the Welcome Trust Sanger Institute, received funding to generate a genome and transcriptome sequence for the potato cyst nematode some years ago.
We have a full genome sequence for this nematode.
This was published last year, but we were also able to generate a series of transcriptome datasets.
RNA SEQ datasets from across the lifecycle of the nematode, and these are fully fully replicated, so we have our own ASIC from eggs.
Second stage juveniles, several parasitic stages and the adult stages as well.
And this is an incredible incredibly powerful resource for understanding the biology of this pathogen.
So I work with effectors.
How am I going to use these beautiful transcriptome and genome resource?
Is that we've generated so I work with effectors and I have a very broad definition of what an effector is.
So in my book and effector is anything that the nematode secretes into the plant that manipulates the plant to the benefit of the nematode.
Effectors are important because they played key roles in all of these.
Process is throughout the nematode life cycle and in plant parasitic nematodes.

They're made in two sets of gland cells, so this is a sketch of the front end of an invasive juvenile nematode, and there are three gland cells, two submental gland cells and one dorsal gland cell, and the effectors that the nematode puts into the plant are made here and there secreted out through the front of the nematode.
Through this style it here.
This is hollow protrusible spear like structure.
And the nematode uses for feeding, but also for introducing effectors into the plant.
So effectors play key roles throughout the lifecycle, and they are made in plant cells.
So how do we go about identifying our effectors from playtest nematodes?

Well, the easiest way to do it is simply to look at the work that my friends and colleagues have done across the world and look for the matching genes in powder that they found another limited, but of course we want to do things a little bit more thoroughly than that.
And so we have a bioinformatic pipeline that can use the genome and transcriptome resource.

Is that we've generated to find knew effector candidates and affect us because they're sick rayted we know they should have a signal peptide, and also because of the life cycle, we know they should either be upregulated when the nematode wants to invade the plant, or upregulated when it's setting up the feeding site in the plant, so we can develop a bioinformatic pipeline that uses the RNA SEQ data we've generated before to identify candidate effectors.

And because we know that these things should be expressed in gland cells, if their effectors, we can confirm or otherwise, whether their effectors or not by using something called in in situ hybridization, which is asking the question, where in the nematode is my new gene being expressed, and in these cases here we can see a series of genes that are expressed in the dorsal glance.
Also, these tick the boxes to be ineffective.
So we have lots and lots of potential effectors.
Some of these things exist in huge gene families, so we need to prioritize them so we have a series of tests we can use to try and identify what we believe are the important effectors.
First of all, we can say are they present in a range of populations, or are they always there in the nematode, as the nematode?
Need this sequence we can look at when when these things are expressed?
So here is some of our RNA SEQ data where we're looking at expression of certain genes.
Each line is gene expression profile across the across the lifecycle of the nematode.
And these effectors are all highly upregulated when the nematodes infecting the plant, and these are highly upregulated when it's parasitic.
So if you're interested in particular biological process is, we can focus in on these effects.

We can ask the question is these are these effectors essential we can use our nei to knockout expression of these things, so here's one example where we've grown the nematodes on plants expressing double stranded RNA targeting effector.
So in this way we can look at which are the essential effectors.
And then finally we can also ask the question where did the number to defectors go once they're inside the plants?
And here's an effective it goes to the peroxisomes and here's one that's in the trailer.
So we've got a variety of tests we can use to identify what we believe to be important effectors and essential effectors for the nematode that we then focus our efforts on.
So what do effectors do?
Well, some of them suppress host defenses.
We've said offset already that these nematodes make feeding structures that they've got to keep alive for many weeks.
And it's so perhaps it's not surprising that they can switch off plant defense responses.
So here's one effector called Sprite 12.
It's expressed in the dorsal gland cell.
And I don't know how well you can see that.
But essentially, if you express this effector in the plant and then expose it to a combination of resistance in a virulent stream, that should induce cell death.
So here are two controls you can see their cell death here and here.

Here is an effective that does not suppress defenses, and I don't know how well you can see that this cell death there, but in the presence of this particular effect, are there is no cell death or vary greatly reduced cell death when you would expect it?
So here we can see that the nematode produces effectors that switch off plant defense responses.
What else do they do?
We've also found effectors that can manipulate the host as a food source, so here is another of these.

Price Check effect is called surprise 17 if we look to see what plant proteins it interacts with using a yeast two hybrid screen, we find it will interact with something called potato, carrot, carotenoid cleavage, dioxygenase full.
It's a very strong interaction in Easton.
We test using a split wife pee test.
Whether this happens in the plant we can see that these two proteins do indeed interact.
So what is CCD 4?
Well, it's a character as I said.

Not annoyed cleavage dioxygenase and one of my colleagues Mark Taylor had made a series of potato lines in which expression of this CCD four was knocked out using RNA I and what we find is that if you put nematodes on those potato plants, they show greatly increased ability to infect into plans and you get far more females in these plants as well.
So silencing of the host target leads to increased carotenoid levels in the plants.
An increased ability of the nematodes to infect.
An interesting Lee.
This is a wild potato called Salon and Foreca and this is a variety potato that has naturally low levels of CD four and is naturally high in carotenoids.

You can see that if you look at the tubers, if they have a Golden yellow color because of the increased level of carotenoids and it turns out that salon and foreca is highly susceptible to potato cyst nematode.
So what we have here is an example of a nematode effector that we think inactivate CCD four implants and what that does is it improves the feeding site as a.
The nutritional quality of the feeding site for the nematodes benefit.
So one of the advantages of working at a Research Institute like ours is the time I get the opportunity to work with colleagues that work on different plant pathogens.
People that work on bacterial pathogens, fungal pathogens, and who am I see pathogens, and one of the things that we were interested in as a team here, is common host targets of effectors.

So there was a study performed in Arab topsis some years ago now, which tested the ability of all the Arab adoptions proteins to interact with all the other Arab opsis proteins, and this diagram here is summarizes what you find if you do that and that's.

Some proteins interact with one or two or very few partners, whereas others which are called hubs seem to interact with lots and lots of different proteins, and these are key control nodes in host biochemistry, and it turns out that these are more likely to be attacked by pathogens.
It's very attractive.
Hit one of these hubs if you're a pathogen, because he means by taking out one host protein you can manipulate a whole area of host biochemistry.
So one of the questions we've been looking at is, do fantasist nematode effectors target similar proteins?
Do they target these hubs in the same ways other plant pathogens?
So this is a story very briefly about one effect tickle 16 H O2.

It was interesting to us in the 1st place because when you expressed in plants with the GFP tag, it goes to the endoplasmic reticulum, which is, which is quite unusual and something similar had been seen for the late, for one effector from a late blight pathogen fight off their investments, and this interacts with the neck transcription factor.
And we we went and looked further at the 16 H O2 effector and found that this also interacts with the neck transcription factor.
If we then take our effector and make genetically modified plants overexpress it, what we find is that these plants are more susceptible to the late blight pathogen.

Compare the control lines here with the overexpression lines here, so the presence of this nematode effector which is hitting the same host target as the final flight, one of the fight author effectors increases the ability of fight offer to infect plants.
So what our next transcription factors?
They're basically stress response transcription factors there.

Pre made and they live in the endoplasmic reticulum, which explains the localization that we saw previously and under in stress conditions they are immediately cleaved and the transcription factor goes to the nucleus, where it can activate gene expression.
There are very rapid response to environmental stresses.
And this we see this is what our effector is doing.
Is it stopping that normal relocalization from happening?
So if we look at the net transcription factor target and where it goes in plants, it lives in the nucleus under the conditions were using, it's going to the nucleus and it's active.

However, when we Co Express our affecter what this shows is that transcription factor is retained in the endoplasmic reticulum, so the nematode effector stops that transcription factor from going to the nucleus, which is a very similar mode of action to the late Blight effect that we've seen.
So we have an example here of conserved targets of effectors from diverse pathogens.
OK, so I'm going to finish up with a couple of slides here that tried to answer the question what is the point of all this work?
Yes, we can generate very beautiful images.
We can get some nice paper, but what's the practical relevance of this?
So this is either don't propose to go through this.
Don't panic.
This is the zigzag model.
It's a different Jones, someone far more clever than me that summarizes the different layers of plants, defense responses, and really the key point is this one.
So plants recognize the pathogen.
Like telling me to hurry up so plants recognize the pathogen induced the first layer of defense is.
And what effect does do is they switch off these defenses and the second layer of defenses is resistance.
Genes and resistance genes operate by recognizing effectors OK.
So when an effector is recognized, it's in a virulent stream, and we can use these to screen for resistance.
So one, a virulence gene from nematodes from Texas nematode is being found.
It's called RBP.
One and it's recognized by resistance Gene GPA too, so this AVR gene is now an extremely useful tool to follow where the resistance genes in at Gino's in a breeding program.
So here is a potato leaf on the top two spots are controls.
This is a cultivar called's area which does not have the GPA 2G.
This is a positive control spot here in here.
This potato cultivar does have the GPA to resistance tree and if we just express this a verb and stream in the in the here we can see up.
We can see that we get a Patch of cell death, but in the line that doesn't have the resistance gene, we don't get that sell there.
So I an effector that is recognized as an extremely valuable tool for finding resistance in a breeding line.
It's far easier to do this than doing nematode an infection.
So we have generated as part of the global dear Powder Genome Project.
Lots and lots of sequence from lots and lots of different populations of nematodes, and what this is in, So we can combine the knowledge we have about effectors.
What are the essential effectors, water, the effectors that the nematode can't do without?
What are the effectors that are present in all these different lines here?
And we can start to look at variation in these effective sequences and see if it correlates with violence against various resistance store sources.
And so these effectors, connectors probes that allow us then to go and find the corresponding resistance genes.
And if we can identify a really essential, really important effector, then we can look for resistant.
That recognizes that effector because it's likely to be durable.
So hope that wasn't too painful for the first talk in the morning.
To summarize, we've identified lots of effectors from Palador and their host targets.
We know that effectors go to a diverse range of plant structures that we have identified the function of.
Some of these effectors.
They may suppress defenses, or they manipulate manipulate the plant to make it a better food source for the nematode.

We've also been able to show that effect is from completely diverged pathogens late by two in my seat and nematodes have similar host targets, and I hope I persuaded you that effectors can be used as tools that allow us to to breed resistance and durable resistance in plants.

So as I said at the start, this sort of work is done by teams and this is the composition of the nematology team, or just I won't go through the mall by just mentioned Vivian Block who's in the audience and talking later Vivian and I have led the nematode team at their Institute together for many years now and also the work that we do for most part of this Dundee affected consortium, looking at effectors from a wide range of plant pathogens, and I'll stop there.
